results.headline: The Saintly and the Loutish Share a Violent London

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Redemption (Hummingbird)

results.summary_short: The action star Jason Statham duets with Agata Buzek as a nun in “Redemption,” Steven Knight’s directorial debut.

results.headline: A Protopunk Band With Bonds of Steel

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Band Called Death

results.summary_short: The music documentary “A Band Called Death” catches up with a groundbreaking punk group that emerged in 1970s Detroit.

results.headline: Think Fertilizer Is Yucky? Try This Kind

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 100 Bloody Acres

results.summary_short: In “100 Bloody Acres,” two brothers seize on an inventive strategy to keep their fertilizer business going.

results.headline: A Lifetime of Songwriting, as Sung by Her Children

results.summary_short: Lian Lunson’s “Sing Me the Songs That Say I Love You” traces Kate McGarrigle’s musical legacy, as her songs are performed in concert by her children, Rufus and Martha Wainwright.

results.display_title: How to Make Money Selling Drugs

results.summary_short: Matthew Cooke wrote and directed “How to Make Money Selling Drugs,” and also narrates his documentary.

results.headline: These Dead Don’t Walk. They Run.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of World War Z

results.summary_short: The love-scare affair with zombies is exploited yet again in “World War Z,” with Brad Pitt as the hero trying to save the world as well as his family.

results.headline: First a Bombing, Then a Truth That’s Elusive

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Attack

results.summary_short: In “The Attack,” a Palestinian, tries to prove that his wife was not a suicide bomber.

results.headline: A Young Couple Take a Bite of Southern Noir

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rushlights

results.summary_short: When a woman dies, her identity is used to con someone out of cash in Antoni Stultz’s “Rushlights.”

results.headline: A College Where the Exams Are Terrifying

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Monsters University

results.summary_short: Pixar’s “Monsters University” tells the story of how Mike and Sulley of “Monsters Inc.” met, became friends and learned to be really scary.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Maniac

results.summary_short: Elijah Wood stars as a stalker killer in “Maniac,” a remake of a 1980 thriller.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kuichisan

results.summary_short: Photography dominates in Maiko Endo’s new film “Kuichisan,” a folk tale told in voice-over.

results.headline: Devoted To Choir, In Life And Death

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Unfinished Song

results.summary_short: “Unfinished Song” belongs to the school of “The Full Monty” and “Calendar Girls” in its vision of stolid, working-class Britons banding together.

results.headline: When My Music Was Your Music

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Downloaded

results.summary_short: “Downloaded” documents the development and emasculation of Napster, the music file-sharing system.

results.summary_short: Men connect through their troubles — some not so troubling — in “Bert and Arnie’s Guide to Friendship.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Hijacking

results.summary_short: In Tobias Lindholm’s drama “A Hijacking,” tension unfolds between pirates and a shipping company.

results.headline: The Condemned Man and His Two Burdens

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In The Fog

results.summary_short: Sergei Loznitsa’s “In the Fog” follows a suspected Nazi collaborator toward his fate in a Russian forest.

results.headline: Where Being Gay Is a Life-and-Death Struggle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Call Me Kuchu

results.summary_short: The documentary “Call Me Kuchu” chronicles the struggles of the gay rights movement in Uganda, and its prime mover, David Kato, who was bludgeoned to death in January 2011.

results.summary_short: “Far Out Isn’t Far Enough” is a portrait of the acclaimed book illustrator Tomi Ungerer, who ruffled feathers with his subversive art.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hatchet III

results.summary_short: “Hatchet III,” the latest installment in the Hatchet series, follows Victor Crowley as he wields his murderous power tool.

results.headline: Car Trouble of the Unexpected Kind
